title: All accounts are in my husband name I am a stay at home mom, if we were to divorce would I have any legal rights to the money?
question: My husband handles all financial aspects of our home, I can not even check the accounts on-line he refuses to allow access. I am worried that if we divorce I will have not rights to any money and be unable to care for my two young children, in turn he will get full custody
question_tags: Divorce,Bank accounts in divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Inheritance and divorce,Community property in divorce,Child support,Alimony,Divorce and bankruptcy,Child custody,Family court and child custody cases,Temporary child custody,Bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and alimony,Bankruptcy and debt,Dividing property in a divorce,Divorce and family,Dividing assets in a divorce,Child support and custody,Inheritance rights,Mother's rights in child custody,Lawsuits and disputes,Family law,Fees
answers: The law would entitle you to share equally in assets acquired during marriage, including bank accounts, regardless of whether only your husband's name has been on those accounts, or if he has been the only person managing those accounts. Such assets that have to be shared would be characterized as "community property". The law also requires that you and your husband disclose all of your current assets and debts, and you will also have the right to conduct further discovery if you have reason to believe that he has not been complete in his disclosures. You may also have the right to child and spousal support, and to ask for your husband to pay for attorney fees. An important note is that you are only entitled to support starting from the date you file a Request for Order in court. You should consider consulting with a lawyer to help you determine what you may possibly receive for support and in the division of assets so you can have an idea of what to expect after you file.

California law provides that all assets acquired during marriage, except for those acquired by inheritance or gift, are community property and each spouse is entitled to one-half of those assets. If he is working and you are a stay at home mom, you are entitled to spousal support and child support. If you separate, you will want to file a Request for Order asking for temporary custody of the children and for spousal and child support and if you hire an attorney, include a request for attorney's fees. (You may be ordered to seek work). California law also states that both parties have an obligation to disclose all assets and debts to the other spouse in the event of a divorce. If he does not disclose the assets and debts, then he has breached his fiduciary duty to you and there are penalties for this. If your name is on any accounts, go down to the bank now and ask for the last statement for all accounts.
